instances.text: CAPS_V 205-001 - Fundamentals of Physiology in Human Health and Disease I

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as âin-personâ are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete. 

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to âWaitlistâ and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
CENS 201: Capital and Commentary, Part I -- Contexts
Marxâs Capital (Das Kapital) is arguably the best known book in the canon of European Studies, and yet also the least read! The challenge, or wager, of this course is to read Capital as a literary, philosophical, sociological, historical, political and economic experiment in thinking otherwise about our past, present, and future. Together weâll explore how Marxâs passion for both interpreting and changing the modern world speaks to his own context as well as to ours, with a focus on his ideas about class exploitation, settler colonialism, the gendered division of labour, chattel slavery, economic crises, and ecological breakdown. Knowledge of languages other than English, including but not limited to German, is an asset but not a prerequisite!

Interested in checking out other courses from the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies?  Click here to learn more.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This course on Great Works of Literature from Central, Eastern and Northern Europe is taught in English and discusses European identities from a decentred point of view. Its goal is to question where Europe begins, ends, and where its centre could be located, culturally and geographically. We critically review hierarchies of power in a short story by Franz Kafka, the colonial context of European history by reading a fairy tale by Danish author Hans Christian Andersen, discuss how Germany dealt with the Holocaust after 1945 (Bernhard Schlink: The Reader), and look at Europe from the East by focusing on post-communist Europe and the âBalkanâ region (Slavenka DrakuliÄ: CafÃ© Europa Revisited). We will also study journalistic writings and documentaries that deal with the EU extension in 2004.
Â 
This course is designed to strengthen critical thinking by comparing texts and film adaptations from different countries and periods. All course material is in English. There are no prerequisites. Major texts are available as ebooks. Additional sources will be available on UBC Canvas. The course is taught fully online: All assignments for the asynchronous parts and all Zoom lecture notes (ppt) of the synchronous online lessons on Tuesdays will be posted on Canvas.

More information here.

Interested in learning more about other courses in the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies? Click here

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
If you are a curious mind, join this course to sharpen your critical thinking skills and enhance your ability to navigate an increasingly deceptive present-day life. This course views the intricate world of falsehoods through interdisciplinary lenses, examining the psychology behind lying, the mechanics of deception and ways of detecting it, historical contexts, ethical dimensions, and modern-day manifestations of manipulation as well as the proliferation of disinformation in contemporary political and media landscapes.

Check out more courses from the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies by clicking here

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This course focuses on aspects of catastrophe and gender, humans and animals in a range of works from central, eastern, and northern European literatures from late medieval to modern times. It opens with mythologies of creation and catastrophe and discourses of eco-criticism in feminist and indigenous perspectives. The course readings fall into four modules, treating a wide range of narrative prose works that deal with seismic upheavals, plague epidemics, apocalyptic and dystopian visions, ecological, technological and social disaster, nuclear accidents and warfare. This course has no prerequisites. It is taught in English and all relevant material studied will be provided in English translation. This class is taught in mixed mode, with in-class as well as online assignments and meetings.

Check out more courses from the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies here.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Learn more about courses offered in the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies by clicking here.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Cross listed with NORD 341.In the face of new and unprecedented environmental and economic challenges in the Arctic, Indigenous peoples have mounted resistance efforts both inside and outside their communities to retain sovereignty over their lands and ways of life. This course explores the neocolonialism of circumpolar regions, and looks at the ways that Indigenous peoples have engaged in resistance and revitalization through collective action and art. This course fulfills the place and power requirement. 

Interested in learning about other courses within the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies? Click here.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
XMT section is ONLY for students who are REATTEMPTING this course. If you didnât pass the course before, but you had a passing lab score, please register for a lecture, a lab and XMT wait list. 
Â 
Department will manually check your lab score and your eligibility for XMT. If eligible, students on the wait list will receive an email notification to accept the XMT spot. Once registered into XMT, your previous lab score will be reused.
Â 
If students mistakenly wait list for XMT, you will be removed from the wait list without further notice.
Â 
If students are attempting the course for the first time, please register for a lab, i.g. L06, L07, etc.

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
